page.title: 18WOODLANDS-CATTERICK-TUNSTALL
page.content: A number of woods are self planted. That is to say seeds from trees have taken root where they have fallen and with the passing of time a woodland has been created. Birds and the wind have also carried and introduced different species into a copse. This has happened in disused quarries and what was once a Lime Kiln. These self planted woods tend to be deciduous whereas the plantations tend to be coniferous, man prefering the protection given by the fir trees against the prevailing winds. A bridle path leads from the Lime Kiln wood area across the fields to Tunstall and horse riders exercise their rights to use it. A right of way stretches from Low Green Catterick to Brough Park and this is a very popular walk with dog owners.
